name: 3 Muskteers
description: Similar to the Milky Way, the 3 Musketeers bar is made of fluffy, whipped nougat covered in chocolate. It originally came with three flavors in one pack — chocolate, vanilla, and strawberry — hence the name.

name: Oh Henry!
description: One of the first combination candy bars, the Oh Henry! — is a mix of peanuts, caramel, and fudge coated in chocolate.

name: Hersheys Milk Chocolate Bar
description: The bar that started it all, although the slightly sour taste is still somewhat different

name: Health Toffee Bar
description: Made of toffee, almonds, and milk chocolate, the Heath Toffee Bar is originally marketed as health bar. The tagline? Heath for better health!

name: Clark Bar
description: Similar to the Butterfinger, the Clark Bar has a crispy peanut butter and spun taffy core.

name: Mounds
description: One of the simpler and more enduring candy bars out there, this shredded coconut and dark chocolate confection remains a favorite to this day.

name: Baby Ruth
description: The Baby Ruth bar — which is supposedly named for President Grover Cleveland's eldest daughter and not the famous baseball player — was originally marketed as an energy bar and a complete luncheon for 5c.

name: Hersheys Gold Peanuts & Pretzels
description: Only the fourth candy bar to carry the Hershey's name, the Gold is another chocolate-free treat, with peanuts and pretzels baked into caramelized creme.

name: Butter Finger Bar
description: In an early marketing campaign, the Curtiss Candy Company dropped Butterfingers with tiny parachutes from airplanes, which is very adorable.

name: Milky Way
description: Made of chocolate malt nougat topped with caramel and covered in milk chocolate, the Milky Way bar is modeled after a popular milkshake at the time.

name: Charleston_Chew
description: Featuring nougat in a chocolate coating, this classic candy bar — named after the Charleston, a popular dance in the 1920s — originally came in four flavors: chocolate, vanilla, strawberry, and banana (that one was eventually phased out).

name: Reese's Peanut Butter Cup
description: This iconic sweet was originally developed by H.B. Reese, a former shipping foreman for candy magnate Milton S. Hershey.

name: Snickers
description: If Snickers is your favorite chocolate bar, you're not alone. It's nabbed the top spot in lists of America's best-selling candies for years.

name: Payday
description: One of the few chocolate-free candy bars, PayDays consist of salted peanuts rolled in caramel, surrounding a nougat-like center.

name: Kit-Kat
description: It was invented by Rowntree's, but Hershey acquired a license to produce Kit Kats, and they've been a top-selling candy bar here ever since

name: Nestle Crunch
description: One of the original crisped rice milk chocolate bars, the Crunch's direct competitor is the Krackel, introduced by Hershey that same year.

name: Almond Joy
description: It took the makers of Mounds 26 years to realize that sometimes you feel like a nut.

name: Caramello
description: Hands down, one of the sweetest candy bars you can eat. Also, one of the best to blend into a milkshake.

name: Hersheys Cookies 'N' Creme
description: Hershey's chocolate Cookies 'n' Creme is similar in taste to an Oreo with a slight tangyness

name: Take 5
description: With pretzels, caramel, peanuts, peanut butter, and milk chocolate, the Take5 is one of the first candy bars to contain all the stuff.
